title: Shares in Shire tumble after dry eye drug setback
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 19, 2015, 16:57 BST - UK Markets closed Shares in Shire tumble after dry eye drug setback By Tara Cunningham | Telegraph – 5 hours ago 60.48 -0.67 
The FDA declined to approve Shire (Xetra: S7E.DE - news ) 's new dry eye drug sending shares in the company towards the bottom of the FTSE 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in pharmaceutical company Shire fell after US health regulators declined to approve its new treatment for dry eye disease. 
On Friday night, the US Food and Drug administration (FDA) informed the Anglo-Irish company of its decision a week before it was due. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) has requested more information related to quality of the new drug, called Lifitegrast, as well as data from an additional clinical study. 
This morning Shire said it remained committed to working with the FDA to provide the necessary information to deliver its new treatment. 
"We are disappointed, but will soon have data from the phase three study," said Shire boss Flemming Ornskov. 
"This is an unmet medical need for which there has been no new FDA-approved treatment in over a decade." 
The stock tumbled by as much as 2.2pc in early morning trade, as investors digested the bad news. 
Analysts had previously stated that the drug could become a blockbuster $1bn-a-year seller. 
However, analysts at JPMorgan Cazenove said the FDA's decision should not have come as a surprise to the market, as the pharmaceutical company had already warned of the risk of a delay. 
James Gordon, of JPMorgan Cazenove, said: "Today we expect the market to push back the Lifitegrast launch by around eight months." 
With the drug approval delayed, Mr Gordon said the market may now deem Shire (Amsterdam: QB8.AS - news ) "less likely" to undertake significant equity-funded M&A, which could be seen as a positive point. 
Analysts at Bank of America Merrill Lynch believe the FDA’s decision could adversely impact its bid for Baxalta (Berlin: 9BX.BE - news ) . 
Two months ago, Shire made a $30bn bid for Baxalta, a US-based maker of drugs for rare diseases. Although Baxalta rejected the offer, Shire has said it remained committed to the deal. 
Bank of America Merrill Lynch warned the FDA's decision on Lifitegrast "could extend the Baxalta overhang", given that a revised all-share offer by Shire could be difficult ahead of a major event for its stock, such as the clinical trial. 
Only last week, shares in Shire rallied amid rumours it was preparing a bid for US drugs developer Radius Health (Xetra: 1R8.DE - news ) . 
On Friday, peer AstraZeneca (Swiss: AZN.SW - news ) fell when its diabetes drug was not approved by the FDA, which requested more clinical data. 
Shares in Shire hit a high in August, but the stock has slipped 23pc since and is now changing hands at £44.32. Shire 5-day graph (Source: Bloomberg)
